The "Common Sense Drug Policy Act of 2000" includes provisions for major drug trafficking prosecution, protection of women in prisons, increased funding for substance abuse prevention and treatment in the federal prison system, prosecutorial data collection, and clean start with expungement. The "Common Sense Drug Policy Act of 2000" includes expungement provisions for major drug trafficking prosecution. Congress finds that mandatory minimum sentencing for drug offenses has led to a significant increase in the Federal Bureau of Prisons budget. This has not reduced sentencing discretion but has shifted it from judges to prosecutors, resulting in disparities in sentencing. Additionally, African Americans are disproportionately represented in federal drug convictions compared to their population and drug use rates. In 1986, before mandatory minimums for crack cocaine offenses, African Americans received 11% higher prison sentences than whites. After mandatory sentencing laws, African Americans received 49% higher drug offense sentences. The average drug dealer holds a low-wage job and sells part-time to fund their drug use. Time spent in prison does not affect recidivism rates according to a 1999 Justice Department report. Title II focuses on the protection of women in prisons, specifically addressing the safety and well-being of women inmates. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to provide assurances to the Attorney General regarding policies in jails and correctional facilities that restrict male employees' roles with women inmates. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to restrict male employees' roles with women inmates, including prohibiting body searches, addressing health needs, limiting restraints on pregnant women, and providing protections for those reporting violations. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to impose disciplinary action on jail employees for violations, require termination of male employees committing misconduct against female inmates, and mandate programs addressing women inmates' prior victimization and high-risk behaviors. The text chunk discusses the requirements for correctional facilities to ensure the health care needs of women inmates are met, including assessments, compliance with standards, crisis intervention programs, and meeting basic health care service standards. The text chunk focuses on the requirements for State corrections departments to assess minority health needs in correctional settings and analyze health services for women inmates to classify their health and security risks. Increased funding for prevention and treatment of substance abuse in the federal prison system is addressed in Title III. The Attorney General, in collaboration with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will implement a program for substance abuse prevention and treatment in Federal penal institutions. Special consideration will be given to individuals with less than 12 months left in their criminal custody. Authorization of appropriations is provided. SEC. 302. The Attorney General must require Federal criminal prosecutors to report the race, ethnicity, and gender of individuals charged with a Federal offense, as well as details of plea bargains, at each stage of prosecution. The Attorney General shall report this information annually to Congress. SEC. 402. STATE DATA. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to require each state to report the race, ethnicity, and gender of individuals charged with criminal offenses to the Attorney General. Additionally, details of plea bargains must be included in the report. The Attorney General is mandated to annually report this information to Congress. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 requires states to report demographic information of individuals charged with criminal offenses to the Attorney General, including details of plea bargains. The Attorney General must then annually report this information to Congress. TITLE V--CLEAN START

SEC. 501. EXPUNGEMENT.

    (a) Section 404 of the Controlled Substances Act is amended to allow for expungement of offenses meeting specific criteria, including completion of a substance abuse program and no further criminal convictions post-conviction.
